awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Exploration of Data-Driven Methods for Cyber Manufacturing
awd_abstract_narration:
This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project will investigate the knowledge and data-driven and cyber-enabled tools needed to link design and manufacturing, thereby enabling a cyber manufacturing marketplace that identifies the on-demand manufacturing capabilities necessary for rapid realization of product designs. Such a marketplace can democratize access to “know-how” and means of production on a massive scale, by seamlessly connecting designers with manufacturers in a broad platform of regional and global supply chains and democratizing access to manufacturing capabilities without compromising manufacturers’ “know-how” and trade secrets.

To realize this impact, it is necessary to (1) create data-driven methods to harvest knowledge of manufacturing capabilities that can transform a computer-aided design (CAD) into the desired physical product, and (2) create methods to efficiently search for this knowledge through the cyber infrastructure. The project hypothesizes that: (i) computing machines can learn the manufacturing capabilities required to transform a CAD model into the desired physical part from available design and manufacturing data, and (ii) efficient cyber-enabled search of the required manufacturing capabilities for a part design can be realized through statistical similarity-based search methods. The hypothesis will be tested through innovative and convergent data-driven approaches that utilize expertise in computer-aided design, manufacturing science and technology, and machine learning.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this EAGER project was to explore data-driven computational methods to infer the core knowledge required for automating the translation of computer-generated three-dimensional designs of discrete products (computer-aided designs) into their physically manufactured counterparts from design and manufacturing data. These methods are expected to eventually enable the creation of future cyber manufacturing marketplaces for rapid on-demand manufacturing and supply of products.

Specific research objectives of the project were to (1) create machine learning methods to automatically infer knowledge of the shape, material, and part quality transformation capabilities of discrete manufacturing processes, (2) create machine learning methods to efficiently search for “similar” part designs requiring similar manufacturing capabilities to produce them. The educational objective was to educate and train graduate and undergraduate students in various aspects of the design-to-manufacturing translation problem and in using data-driven computational methods to solve them.

The intellectual merit of the project lies in the fundamental knowledge acquired through work aimed at answering the following research questions: 1) Can manufacturing process capabilities be inferred from available design and manufacturing data? If so, how accurately? 2) Can the manufacturing process for a discrete part be ascertained with sufficient accuracy from its geometric similarity to previously produced parts?

Specifically, deep learning approaches investigated in the project showed that it is possible to learn the part shape, transformation capabilities of simple machining operations such as turning, chamfering, grooving, etc. from synthetically generated design and manufacturing data with testing accuracies ranging from 87% to 91% depending on the process. Work on similarity search based automated process selection using both non-machine learning and machine learning approaches demonstrated that deep learning on point cloud representation of three-dimensional part shapes yields testing accuracy of more than 99%. Work on unsupervised deep learning methods for part similarity search showed that use of material property information in addition to part geometry information yields better model accuracy than using part shape information alone. Finally, the project successfully demonstrated the ability of deep learning methods to accurately learn known design-for-manufacturing rules and to utilize the resulting model for automatically converting unmanufacturable and partially manufacturable designs into manufacturable designs.

The broader impacts of this project include successful training of two doctoral students, and two undergraduate students (from a minority serving institution) in modern data-driven modeling methods to solve long-standing problems in automating the design-to-manufacturing workflow. In addition, collaboration with industry researchers at Siemens Corporation in Princeton, NJ through a NSF INTERN Program supplement enabled one of the doctoral students to gain understanding of the industrial challenges in translating a design into a manufactured product, which greatly benefited his research. Knowledge gained from this project also enabled Siemens researchers to understand how the data-driven methods investigated in this project could be used in various industrial applications.

 


Last Modified: 05/28/2024
Modified by: Shreyes N Melkote

    Shreyes Melkote, David Rosen, Mahmoud Dinar
